#Text=World Health Organization calls for ban on tobacco ads
#Text=Sunday , June 1 , 2008
#Text=The United Nations health agency
#Text=the World Health Organization ( WHO ) has called for a ban on tobacco advertising and promotion in order to protect the world 's children .
#Text=The news release from the WHO came on Friday , one day before the annual World No Tobacco Day held each year on May 31 .
#Text=This year 's World No Tobacco Day focuses on highlighting the practices of tobacco companies in their efforts to promote their products to young people .
#Text=According to a WHO press release , studies show that young people are more likely to start smoking if exposed to tobacco advertising .
#Text=The WHO notes that only five percent of the world population " is covered by comprehensive bans on tobacco advertising , promotion and sponsorship " .

#Text=The WHO appeals to member states and policy-makers to require by law a comprehensive ban on all forms of advertising , promotion , and sponsorship of tobacco products ,  said WHO Regional Director for Africa Luis Sambo , in a statement released Saturday in Kampala , Uganda .

column1: #Text=The WHO said that tobacco companies are specifically targeting the half billion youth in the Asia Pacific region by tying smoking to the idea of a flashy lifestyle .
#Text=The agency said the tobacco industry attempts to take advantage of children 's susceptibility to advertising and marketing .
#Text=According to the WHO most people take up smoking before they reach age 18 , and almost twenty-five percent of smokers worldwide are under the age of 10 .

#Text=The agency said that a survey of 13 to 15 year-olds found that fifty-five percent had seen cigarette ads on billboards in the prior month , and twenty-percent owned something with a cigarette company 's logo .
#Text=According to BBC News , in the last ten years female and adolescent smoking in Russia has tripled .
#Text=Russia does not have many anti-smoking laws .
#Text=BBC News compared this to Canada , where smoking levels are at their lowest in 40 years and the country has very restrictive laws on smoking advertising .
#Text=The tobacco industry employs predatory marketing strategies to get young people hooked to their addictive drug .
#Text=— Dr. Douglas Bettcher , Director of WHO 's Tobacco Free Initiative
#Text=" The tobacco industry employs predatory marketing strategies to get young people hooked to their addictive drug .
